												Remember ordering a really cool looking game from a Scholastic Book Order back in school? Well, this game was one the gems I bought in third grade. The title is misleading because you can also drive golfcarts, dune buggies, and even fly planes or helicopters. It still has that same mid-2000s charm! The stadium crowds still punch the stuffing outta each other.I got this for 50% off and love it! Even though I played this as a kid, I wouldn't have bought it at full price considering today's pricing and competition. Runs fine on Windows 10 and doesn't need a CD/password for installation like the old-days.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												Before you look at my hours, I would like you to know that I haven't played this game ever. Not on PS2, Xbox, whatever. However, I did play MX Unleashed when I was a kid, so therefore, I think I can review this game.MX vs. ATV Unleashed is a great racing and freestyle game. Sure, you can play its races, but I barely knew anybody who did that. You know what I mean. All I do is goof off in Free Ride and freestyle. Now, let me talk about the main complaints, which I am going to defend.1. This game doesn't work! A: I know it doesn't always work. In fact, if you have Intel HD graphics, it won't work at all. However, here is how to fix it. Just launch the game and don't change any resolution, graphics, or texture settings. It's that simple. You can change the controls (Like I did because the default controls aren't good) and no crashes. 2. OMG! 30 FPS LOCK?!?!? A: Yes, there is a 30 FPS lock. However, it doesn't affect how the game works. It's not like me where if it happened in an intense, precision game, where you need to instantly make decisions. Plus, this game is almost 10 years old. 60 FPS wasn't always the common things for games. Those were complaints I saw most. I do complain that there is no open world like MX Unleashed. If there was, I would love this game to death. But even still, I still can't hate this game.I would give this a 8/10. Just buy it now. And if you can't fix it, look on forums and then refund it.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
												While this isnt the best racing game you will find on PC, MX Vs. Atv is still a very fun game.Graphics: For a 2006 game, I guess it's average. The tracks look good, and so are the models of the vehicles. I also like the graphical style of the menu. It's nothing special, but I personally like it.Sound: There's quite a lot of songs that were good at the time. If you played this game back in the day, like me, you will feel very nostalgic to hear the in-game music. Though, nowadays, it's nothing to be very excited about, in my opinion.Controls: They're good. But I don't really have much to say about it. You controls the vehicles with the arrow keys, like many other racing games on PC. For the MX and ATVs, there are a few buttons you can press while pressing a direction with the arrows to perform stunts in mid-air. It works very well.Gameplay: This is what the game is best at. You have a lot of choices in vehicles. You would think you get Motos and Quads, but no! You get a few flying vehicles, dune buggies, trophy trucks, golf carts, sand rails, and even Monster Trucks! There are some missions to complete to keep you busy. You can do races, or course. But what I love is the Free Ride mode. You basically just do whatever you want in this mode. And that's what I love to do in this game. And if you are tired of the base tracks, you can even make your very own tracks! And making tracks is easy as well ! The physics aren't the most realistic you could get, but still, they're acceptable. But though, why would you mind the realism of the physics if the game is fun? You'd rather play a fun game with non-realistic physics than a boring game with realistic physics.My only complaint is that since you can easily make levels, it would be awesome to have workshop support for the game, so that you can easily share tracks. But nope! There is, sadly, no workshop support. Overall, this is a good racing game. Or course, there are better alternatives, but if you have a budget computer, this is a game for you. Reccomended!

Posted: November 7, 2015
												Well I'm so happy now that Steam has opened the door to older but still very fun games. Games now are so AAA mainstream and have to have the best graphics and a huge open world. But many forget games like this are what built the foundation for today's AAA titles. These games are classics in my mind and to their true fans they think the same. This game is a 10/10 Easy. The best out of the series although "Untamed" has far more content and things to do. Cheap, simple, fun.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
												Coming at this as being my first foray into the MX vs. ATV series, I have to say that I find this game a mixed bag.The game isn't bad. For a game from 2006 it's actually pretty decent, if nothing impressive visually. Controls work well with a 360 controller and even support both joysticks for camera rotation, something that older pre-Xinput games didn't always do, and the racing mechanics are solid enough.All that said, even in 2006 there were better games you could have been spending your money on. The game looks and feels like a budget title even for the time, with the licensed soundtrack being the title's real high point. The AI rubber bands like nobody's business, a feature racing games still have a problem with, and the lack of real impact your bike or ATV has on the course makes for a game that just doesn't feel great to play. Combined with limited graphical and gameplay tuning options and you have an experienced that is easily surpassed by any number of titles both on and off Steam.The price point isn't terrible, but feels like it is somewhat more than the game deserves given its limitations and the game's overall forgettable nature. On the plus side, the game runs fine first-boot on Windows 8.1 with a full suite of modern hardware, so if you do decide to take the plunge there is little in the way of configuration needed to get it to run, though widescreen support would have been nice to see.Recommended, but only for the fact that those with some sense of nostalgia for it shouldn't be disappointed by this version or its ability to run. For newcomers, though? Look elsewhere.
